origin_of_ch_char_book: For ancient East Asian people, nature was to be revered. When they gazed upon the clear night skies and many stars above, they thought that the stars were like spirits of people. (æ˜Ÿ, xing=hsing star) When we see this character, it shows the green plants (å±®) coming up from the earth (åœŸ), which symbolizes full of life (ç”Ÿ, sheng, to live, life), and stars scattered around it (æ™¶, jing, brilliant; crystal). In ancient dictionary, it was explained that â€œstars are spirits of all living thingsâ€. According to the explanations, the stars or the constellations are related to the spirits of living things. Why did the ancient people connect the stars with the spirit?
humanum_full_description_en:
"å±®" evolved from the pictograph of "è‰¸" without the second half of the writing. It is a variant of "è‰¸". (Qiu Xigui, Chen Jian) "è‰¸" is the original word for " grass ". "Xunzi. "Fu Guo": "The thorns in the valleys and the many manure fields are the business of the farmers." Yang Qi's note: "The words of the ancient grass." "Chu Ci. Nine sighs. "Long Pass": "The wood shook down, and the time was haggard." Hong Xingzu's supplementary note: "The grass is the same as the grass."

According to later usage, "å±®" seems to apply only to grass, not wood. However, Oracle does not seem to distinguish the three radicals of "å±®," "è‰¸, " and " wood ", so the three are often used interchangeably. For example , the word "å›¿" is derived from both "å±®" and " wood ", see "å›¿".

The oracle "å±®" is suspected to be used as a sacrificial name, "Compilation" 27218: "Xin Tanao Qiyi." Liu Xinglong thought the effect was to use newly brewed fragrant wine to hold a grass sacrifice to Zuyi. Another "å±®" is also seen in "Collection" 19811: "Wu Qi to ğ¤‰² (ç‡) éš¹", its intention is unknown.

Bronze inscriptions are used as the names of people, and Zha is from Yi: "Zha (made) is from Yi."

The characters of the Warring States Period are used as the original meaning, the same as " grass ", "Guodian Jian. "Six Virtues" Jane 12: "Only (though) can (in) the å±® (the grass) and the ma (mao)."
humanum_short_description_en: "å±®" evolved from the pictograph of "è‰¸", omitting the second half. It is a variant of "è‰¸".
